Ed Benguiat told a student that the way you can identify Franklin Gothic is to look at the lowercase c. It looks like a keyhole turned sideways, and since Ben Franklin used a key in his electrical experiments it has to be Franklin Gothic.   
   
I love it.

I think there was a discussion here a while back about what   
typeface was used for the Microsoft logo.   
   
Obviously, they use ITC Franklin Gothic extensively in the   
corporate identity, but if you look closely at the logo, you   
will see that it is not Franklin Gothic (ITC or otherwise). All   
the obvious Franklin Gothic details (including Benguiat's   
"keyhole") are absent. In fact, it looks as much like   
Helvetica as Franklin Gothic, but not exactly like either.   
   
It seems likely that it started out as one of those two, but   
was redrawn and modified.
